part.title: Add basic descriptive data
part.para: The next step is to add some basic descriptive data to your resources, such as labels and descriptions. Without these, your resources will still be in the index, but a search on the Acropolis API won't find them.

At this point, it's also useful to add any basic metadata you have to the RDF, such as the creator of a creative work, the date when something was created, any museum identifiers, ISBNs or similar etc.

To add these basic descriptive statements, use the RDFS (prefix: rdfs), Dublin Core (DC) Terms (prefix: dcterms) and FOAF (prefix: foaf) vocabularies. The table below shows some of the ways you can convert existing data to RDF statements:

seglistitem.seg: Resource R has a title (e.g. a proper name)

seg.literal: R dcterms:title "Mr. Ghost Goes To Town"@en-gb

seglistitem.seg: Resource R doesn't have a proper name but has a label

seg.literal: R rdfs:label "The desiccated hand of a thief"@en-gb

seglistitem.seg: Resource R has a long description

para.literal: R dcterms:description "A melting watch draped over a tree"@en-gb

seg.literal: R dcterms:abstract "This documentary is about waiting"@en-gb

seglistitem.seg: Resource R has an identifier specific to its dataset (e.g. a unique catalogue number in a museum collection)
Resource R has a creator (e.g. author, artist, developer, designer) C (where C can be a literal string or another resource)
Resource R depicts or is about resource S
Resource R has a related web page W (e.g. a page about resource R, or about a topic closely-related to it)

part.para: rdfs:label, dcterms:title, rdfs:comment and dcterms:description are particularly useful, as Acropolis uses these for its human-readable description of a resource, as well as for free-text searches. For example, this resource for Twelfth Night gets its title "Twelfth Night" from rdfs:label and its longer description from rdfs:comment.

The DC Terms, RDFS and FOAF vocabularies are very general, widely-used, and well understood. If possible, terms from these vocabularies should be your first choice for specifying the basic properties of your resources. However, where there are no suitable terms in these vocabularies, terms from other vocabularies can be used instead. This is where data modelling becomes a craft rather than a science: choosing relevant vocabularies and applying them correctly is a skill in itself, and can be daunting.

One way to approach the task is to use a very generic but broad vocabulary, such as schema.org. This provides a wide range of different terms for describing common types of resource, and covers a considerable range of modelling tasks.
However, schema.org can be too generic for more specialised modelling. If you find that you need a more expressive vocabulary, this list of commonly-used vocabularies provides some alternatives.

One final option is to create your own vocabulary, building on top of existing ones. This option is too complex to cover in this book, but the the RES team are happy to help if you want to go down this route.

section.title: Adding basic descriptive data to the museum's resources
section.para: Considering the museum's resources again, the following RDF can be extracted from the text on the web page:
section.programlisting:
# the helmet; note the foaf:page link to the # original web page which was the foundation for the RDF <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/items/t0001#id> dcterms:identifier "t0001" ; dcterms:title "The Golden Helmet"@en-gb ; dcterms:description "Large gold helmet. The helmet spontaneously fell from its mount on a wall in the main hall in 1529; Conrad, son of Lord Manfred Otranto, was due to wed Isabella that day, but was instead crushed to death by the falling helmet. The helmet was then lost for many years, until, in 1749, it was rediscovered by archaeologist Fuchsia Otranto in the ruins of the old chapel."@en-gb ; foaf:page <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/items/the-helmet> .
# the document about the helmet; note that dcterms:subject is # used to associate the document with the helmet <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/items/t0001> rdfs:label "Data about The Golden Helmet"@en-gb ; dcterms:subject <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/items/t0001#id> .
# the photograph; dcterms:subject associates the photograph with the helmet <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/photos/p0001#id> rdfs:label "Photograph of The Golden Helmet"@en-gb ; dcterms:subject <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/items/t0001#id> ; dcterms:creator "Vlad Dracula" .
# the document about the photograph <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/photos/p0001> rdfs:label "Data about Photograph of The Golden Helmet"@en-gb .
# digital file representing the photograph <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/images/the-helmet-photo.jpg> rdfs:label "Photograph of The Golden Helmet in JPEG format"@en-gb .
